questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and vomiting for 8 hours. He has had around 3–4 episodes of greenish-colored vomit during this period. He has major depressive disorder with psychosis. His mother has Graves disease. Current medications include sertraline and haloperidol. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. He is diagnosed with acute appendicitis and is taken to the operating room for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. The appendix is gangrenous and perforated, and there is purulent fluid in the pelvis. Just after the appendiceal base is ligated, the patient develops muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The end-tidal CO2 is markedly increased. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is the treatment of choice for a thyrotoxic crisis. In patients with untreated hyperthyroidism, acute stress (e.g., infection or surgery) may precipitate a thyrotoxic crisis. In an anesthetized patient, thyrotoxic crisis manifests with fever, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and/or hypertension. Muscle rigidity, as seen here, is not a typical feature of a thyrotoxic crisis. In addition, this patient has no preoperative clinical features that suggest a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism, despite the family history of Graves disease.

B) CORRECT:

Dantrolene is the drug of choice to treat malignant hyperthermia because it prevents generalized muscle contraction by decreasing the concentration of calcium within the muscle cytoplasm. Physiologically, calcium induces contraction of muscle cells, and in the absence of intracellular calcium, muscle fibers cannot contract. An increase in end-tidal CO2 is usually the earliest sign of malignant hyperthermia. It reflects increased production of CO2 (due to accelerated aerobic metabolism) and, subsequently, serum lactate (as a result of the change in anaerobic metabolism), which together cause mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.

Management of patients with malignant hyperthermia includes immediate cessation of potential triggering agents (e.g, volatile anesthetics), hyperventilation with 100% O2, and cooling measures (e.g., ice packs, ice lavage). Susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia can be determined by a caffeine halothane contracture test or genetic testing for mutations in the RYR1 and DHP genes.

C) INCORRECT:

Bromocriptine is not effective in the treatment of malignant hyperthermia but may be used to treat neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). This patient is taking haloperidol, which may predispose him to develop NMS. While patients with NMS also develop fever, hypertension, tachycardia, and muscle rigidity, the onset of NMS is not hyperacute; instead, NMS evolves gradually over 1–3 days. In addition, it usually occurs within 2 weeks of initiating antipsychotic therapy or increasing dosage.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric combination therapy of antibiotics should be administered in this patient with perforated appendicitis until the bacterial resistance pattern has been determined. Empiric antibiotic therapy in the case of appendicitis must also include coverage of anaerobic bacteria (e.g., Bacteroides spp.), as they are a common pathogen in appendicitis. Ceftriaxone does not have anaerobic coverage, and vancomycin only covers gram-positive anaerobes. A different empiric antibiotic regimen with broad coverage including gram-negative anaerobes would be indicated in this patient (e.g., piperacillin and tazobactam). Moreover, this patient requires therapy for malignant hyperthermia.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is the antidote of choice to treat severe serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome may be a complication of therapy with antidepressants, such as sertraline. Although serotonin syndrome may also manifest with hyperthermia, diaphoresis, and muscle hypertonia, it usually occurs after a recent increase in the dose or frequency of antidepressants. This patient has no history of a recent medication change. The absence of other typical features of serotonin syndrome, such as clonus and mydriasis, as well as the marked increase in end-tidal CO2 suggest a different diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Surgical embolectomy may be considered for hemodynamically unstable patients with acute pulmonary embolism (PE) when thrombolysis or anticoagulant therapy is contraindicated (e.g., risk of blood loss during surgery). In an anesthetized patient, PE may manifest with tachycardia. Unlike in this patient, the end-tidal CO2 should be decreased because of impaired pulmonary perfusion. Also, this patient does not have risk factors associated with PE, such as prolonged immobilization or trauma, and does not display any clinical features of deep vein thrombosis, making this condition even less likely.
questions.hint: This patient developed an acute increase in body temperature associated with tachycardia, muscle rigidity, and a marked increase in end-tidal CO2 after receiving anesthesia, which is indicative of malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being struck by a car while crossing the street. She has major depressive disorder with psychosis. Current medications include sertraline and haloperidol. Vital signs are within normal limits. X-ray of the lower extremity shows a mid-shaft femur fracture. The patient is taken to the operating room for surgical repair of the fracture. As the surgeon begins the internal fixation, the patient shows muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The end-tidal CO2 is 85 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The features of malignant hyperthermia (e.g., fever, muscle rigidity, tachycardia, tachypnea, increased CO2 production) are caused by severe, generalized muscle contraction due to increased Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum via the RYR channels. Dantrolene, an RYR antagonist, would prevent this Ca2+ release.
Image Description:

Approx. half of cases of malignant hyperthermia are associated with a mutation in the ryanodine receptor type 1 (RyR-1). RyR-1 is located in the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) of skeletal and cardiac muscle. Physiologically, activated RyR-1 in the skeletal muscle interacts with the dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR), which results in calcium release from the SR into the sarcoplasm.

(1) If a mutation in the RyR-1 is present, certain triggering substances may lead to a pathological stimulation of the receptor, which (2) results in uncontrolled opening and excessive release of calcium from the SR. The contractility of the skeletal muscle increases, which in return increases the metabolism. As the increased oxygen need can no longer be met, the cell's energy supply breaks down and the cell dies.

(3) The first-line treatment for malignant hyperthermia is dantrolene, which interacts with RyR1 and prevents the release of calcium from the SR of the skeletal muscle.

The mechanism shown here is simplified; research on the pathomechanism of the condition and the exact effect of dantrolene is ongoing.

B) INCORRECT:

A femoral fracture is a risk factor for pulmonary fat embolism. In an anesthetized patient, pulmonary embolism may manifest with tachycardia. However, the end-tidal CO2 would be decreased because of impaired pulmonary perfusion and muscle rigidity would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is the antidote of choice to treat severe serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome may be a complication of therapy with antidepressants, such as sertraline. Although serotonin syndrome may also present with hyperthermia, diaphoresis, and muscle hypertonia, it usually occurs after a recent increase in the dose or frequency of antidepressants, which has not been mentioned here. The absence of other typical features of serotonin syndrome, such as clonus and mydriasis, and the marked increase in end-tidal CO2 suggest a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bromocriptine is used to treat neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), not malignant hyperthermia. This patient is taking haloperidol, which may predispose her to develop NMS. While patients with NMS also present with fever, hypertension, tachycardia, and muscle rigidity, the onset of NMS is not hyperacute, as seen here, but evolves gradually over 1–3 days. Furthermore, it usually occurs within 2 weeks of initiating antipsychotic therapy or increasing dosage.

E) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is the treatment of choice for a thyrotoxic crisis. In patients with untreated hyperthyroidism, acute stress (e.g., surgery) may precipitate a thyrotoxic crisis. In an anesthetized patient, thyrotoxic crisis presents with fever, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and/or hypertension. Muscle rigidity, however, is not a typical feature of a thyrotoxic crisis. Additionally, there were no preoperative clinical features to suggest hyperthyroidism in this patient.
questions.hint: After receiving volatile anesthetics and/or depolarizing neuromuscular blocking drugs (e.g., succinylcholine) as part of general anesthesia, patients with mutations affecting the ryanodine receptor (RYR) channels can develop malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy with status asthmaticus is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit. Within hours, he progresses to respiratory failure and requires intubation. Lung examination is significant for diminished breath sounds bilaterally. A chest radiograph shows hyperinflated lung fields.
Arterial blood gas testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


pH
7.16
7.35–7.45


Partial pressure of carbon dioxide (mm Hg)
70
32–48


Partial pressure of oxygen (mm Hg)
76
83–108


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
19
20–28


The patient is started on sevoflurane. Shortly afterward, he develops fever to 41.0°C, tachycardia, and muscle rigidity. His end-tidal carbon dioxide level rises from 65 to 95 mm Hg.
Which one of the following conditions, if present in this patient, is most likely to have contributed to his sudden deterioration?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertension has no association with malignant hyperthermia.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s signs and symptoms (fever, tachycardia, muscle rigidity, and a rapid rise in end-tidal carbon dioxide) are consistent with malignant hyperthermia. Other signs of malignant hyperthermia may include arrhythmia, dark urine, and excessive bleeding. Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased serum creatine kinase levels may also be found on laboratory evaluation. Triggering agents include volatile anesthetic agents such as isoflurane or sevoflurane with or without administration of succinylcholine.

Treatment of malignant hyperthermia includes immediate discontinuation of the trigger agent, rapid delivery of dantrolene, active cooling, administration of 100% oxygen, and increased minute ventilation. Sodium bicarbonate should also be given to treat metabolic acidosis, and calcium chloride should be given for signs of hyperkalemia.

Conditions associated with malignant hyperthermia include myopathies such as Duchenne muscular dystrophy, central core disease, and hypokalemic periodic paralysis. All of these may manifest with varying levels of muscular abnormalities. Patients with no identifiable risk factors who have mutations in the genes encoding for the skeletal muscle ryanodine receptor are susceptible to malignant hyperthermia.

Key learning point: The underlying condition that is most likely to contribute to malignant hyperthermia in a patient who has received sevoflurane is myotonia.

C) INCORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus has no association with malignant hyperthermia.

D) INCORRECT:

Eczema has no association with malignant hyperthermia.

E) INCORRECT:

Prematurity has no association with malignant hyperthermia.
